review_title: Friendly bank to work for- but no pot of gold here
pros:
They allways have work to do  - steady work flow
Lots of expansion going on in APAC region.
Good for getting poached to work elsewhere.  CS is a good name to have on your CV.  Other banks like to hire CS staff.  If you take a job at CS, you will be headhunted by other banks, guaranteed.
Good for training, improving your skills.  CS offer quite innovative products on the market, and have a full range of private and investment banking products.
Possible if you really want, to work at another CS office elsewhere in the world.
This banks rehires staff that previously worked for the bank / revolving door
The people at CS can be fun to work with.  I allways enjoyed my time at CS.
cons:
Salaries / benefits are lower than some other private / investment banks are offering.  Good for the local market, but not competitive with on the international market.  The difference in salaries seems to be growing, as CS are raising profitability by reducing costs.
Huge turnover of staff
Only way to raise your salary is to leave, or work in switzerland
Disorganised.
In the IT, the solution chosen is often the cheapest, not the best.  This ends up costing more in operationals costs later.
Lots of manual work arrounds.
Too much focus on low cost, not quality.
Not sure how much benefit is being produced by CS centers of excellence in various low cost locations arround the world (pune / poland...).  Is this strategy sensible?

pros: The culture is extremely inclusive, the teams are young, energetic and have a good work ethic. There are several employee engagement programmes, more so than other back office and middle office employers in the same industry. Also, if you are looking for career advancement the senior management is more than willing to ensure than you find the right fit within the group. The interaction between junior executives and management is also quite visible through various departmental meetings, conferences, and internal team meetings. The grievances are suitably taken note of and measures are taken to ensure complete job engagement.
cons: If you are in the middle office atmosphere, you are expected to throw in the extra wee hours of work when the systems are not working optimally or there are processing delays due to unexpected back office glitches. But the company likes to support you with free dinners and cab rides so that you would still think you are being cared for.

pros:
I considered the pay to be relatively good, as compared to the salary in the local city.

Work-life balance is good.

The company invested quite a lot of money on training new employees.
cons:
Well, as a software developer, I kind of find such environment is not suitable for me. There are too much bureaucracy in the system. Every time when I need to deploy a very small fix, I need to spend lots of time urging different levels of managers to sign "permission" in order to push it to production. Developers find it hard to access the tools they need; and they spend lots of time on the administrative issues that are not the "core" problems.

There are also too many "slackers" in the company. Some people worked so hard that they can't rest. Some people never work hard and always fake some sick leaves. They all get the same pay.

pros:
Good salary and benefits. Allows Internal mobility.
CS Private Banking has good culture to work with compared to CS First Boston
cons: Contractors sometimes wait for years to be converted. There were many contractors who resorted to underhanded methods to get converted to permanent. There's a huge glass ceiling. You'll need to make a lot of friends to bypass all of that. They use the bell curve system in appraisals (which has proven to fail in Microsoft), which eliminates the poorest among the best, or keeps the best among the worst by a knock off system - where managers vote off people even if they do not know them. We'd have VPs and AVPs back stabbing each other to prove their worth just to survive the bell curve.  There were a lot of reorgs, so  there were many who were promised promotions only to wait another year because they to prove themselves again to the new manager.

review_title: The worst HR teams on the planet ?
pros:
Within the business, very good company culture: humble, polite, principle driven
Good flexible working options and respect for work life balance.
Good pay, even with a lousy bonus
Good job at cutting costs - though quality and ethics have somewhat suffered
cons: Appalled by the very low quality of the HR function, utterly battered by cost cutting, which drove talent away. An absolute lack of communication and collaboration with their client groups, HRBPs and TD only dedicating their time to MDs hoping for an inexistent cascading. Lateral recruitment poorly managing internal mobility, not even able to read a CV and having no clue about what the business is actually doing. Talent Development function only there to event-manage soft skills trainings and having absolutely no interest in developing technical expertise of the teams. HRBPs not even interested in maintaining job descriptions according to new operating business models, in a time of significant transformation. Terrible lack of proactiveness and internal client management. Admin teams unable to record information adequately and manage effectively flexi time arrangements. And worse, no action taken when shortcomings and improvement needs are pointed out.

review_title: Work Life Balance, Less Work (May be depends on project), Lot of Rework wasting money and resource
pros: Work Life Balance, Less Politics, I got a very Good team lead, team lead is easily approachable, a role model for a team lead. infra structure support team is easily reachable and with less hassle. Employee respect is there.
cons: Information transfer from higher management say manager is not transparent, lots of rework and wastage of resources, less quality in work, misuse of production access (lack in quality at the time of development and do post development process in production). Bit tough if your a contract employee in terms of review , appreciation and getting good work in the project. Internal mobility is just formal for contract employee it is just for a name sake , when you resign the HR team ask about internal mobility usage and before that they wont respond.

pros:
1. Reputable Investment Bank with strong fundamentals
2. Strong initiatives that support employee development and encourages career growth through internal mobility
3. Plesant work-life balance and good working culture
cons:
1. Over the years, culture had degraded to the extent that management is retaining bootlickers to good performers. 
2. Middle management from Europe were often moved to Asia, just for the sake of doing so. There are some especially, who simply dont dedicate time and resources to their role. Not to mention, poor team management, lack of engagement, micro-managing, and worst of all, barking around with lack of product knowledge. 
3. Strong focus of Process re-engineering and operational excellence which was around prior to 2012 were no longer appreciated and supported.

pros: Learn new software that helps them in their accounts opening and closing. Nice team members who are always willing to help. A very dynamic company with a fair bit of socialising events.
cons: It really depends on your manager to see what you can get the most out of your experience there. Company politics at its best.

review_title: Gives above average salaries, but will lay off without warning
pros: Pays above average salary and benefits.
cons:
1) Will lay off critical members of team, but not managers, therefore, more work to those left in the team.
2) Too many managers in one team, the guys on the ground don't know who to follow.
3) And since there are too many managers in one team, there's no opportunity for you to move up.
4) Does mass layoffs, so you need to save up, you might be next (your performance doesn't even matter. It seems totally random). 
5) Though they promote internal training programs, there's too much work that you won't have time to  go to training.

pros: Friendly people, Good graduate training program, Great opportunities to learn and take on a lot of responsibilities. Training programs and workshops are excellent, if you find the time to attend them.
cons:
Re-organisation and frequent change of low level strategies are very common. The illogical rules used unofficially in some departments to rate employees on performance reviews every year at the lower levels is an example of this. A lot of time is spent every year on merging some teams and splitting them again a year or 2 down the lane. 

Recognition is not based on merit, so most talented people tend to leave the company after waiting for promotions for several years. Too many managers on every team, so employees on the ground are confused as to whom to follow.

pros: A place for great work life balance (depending on teams though)

Too many people from only one race in IT
Huge ego issue among management
Lack of competitive colleagues

review_title: Fantastic work life balance, helpful colleagues, conservative and stable

job_title: Vice President of A Back-office/Support Services Function

Unnecessary, impractical control processes are imposed that inflate effort, costs, and frustrates the workforce.  Need to be disciplined, smarter and bolder about using technology in the right ways for the right things. Have been in a cost control and reduction mode like forever.  Mid-management morale is not great.  Always feel that jobs are on the line.

review_title: Unfair deling, too much of politics and otherwise OK

review_title: Its lazy as a company and can't move enough fast on critical decisions and opportunities.

cons:
1. Professional growth at CS is very sloppy specially within Information Technology.

pros: it all depends on which project / team / department you are in...there are some with less load and there are some with heavy load.  And the more you demonstrate and go above the ladder.  Visibility is important with management.

review_title: Credit Suisse... worth the ride but the pot of gold is empty....

cons: Salaries compared to the market are poor even for quite challenging roles in back office, graduate recruitment is large and this leads to a lowered cost but no significant hikes in benefits going forwards. Culture across divisions is relatively siloed with specific divisions having a very blinkered approach to recruitment. Its a good place to work in but their overall compensation package isn't something to boast about....

review_title: No meritocracy and too much bureaucracy.
pros: Well-positioned in the market and good work/life balance.
cons: The lack of meritocracy is what bothers me most in this company, something I wouldn't have expected from a bank with such a good reputation in the market.  No matter how good you are it is very difficult to get promoted and management above you will be less qualified than you.  Level of professionals is average to low.  The name of the game is be political and survive.  The company actually does have good policies in general, but only on paper.  Salaries are way below market.

review_title: Poor management and just keeps getting worse
pros: Pretty good on Internal mobility
cons:
- Senior management are incompetent and out of touch
- all the quality people have left and remaining are overpaid and incompetent especially the ones at the top
- massive cost cutting and redundancy in all parts of the bank. Experienced and competent staff are let go and replaced by people that are not even from banking industry 
- constant restructuring resulting in loss of direction, increased operational risks, lack of cohesiveness and massive inefficiencies 
- salary is below market benchmark
- bonuses are low despite good profit  performance. Senior management keeps a big chunk for their own bonuses and leaves little for people below

pros: It's good place if you join as Trainee analyst (TAs) .I couldn't find one.

pros: Priority on internal mobility provided you have done your time, no one can stop you. CS focuses on retaining top talent. Not much in the way of red tape, typical private company environment. Competitive remuneration

Organisation is large, difficulties occur at ground level when coordinating between front, middle and back - this is typical of large companies but not sure if it is being addressed here.

pros: None. There is absolutely no pros to this place. Very very bad place to work in. Absolutely bad working culture.
cons:
Strong Backstabbing culture,and full of Office Politics. Over the past 5 years, Often see colleagues getting bullied. Bullying culture is horrible, and worse part is that Bullying is acceptable. Common to hear shouting, screaming and insults to people of lower rank.
Also very hierarchical. People tend to pretend to be nice to people of higher rank, but change face to treat people of lower rank badly. Toxic bad culture and recommended to avoid this place.

review_title: Compliance career from CS Compliance Professional Practicum
pros:

It provides a great opportunity for fresh grads/young grads who want to enter the financial service industry, especially with a focus on compliance.  CS has a holistic and comprehensive compliance infrastructure, where grads can take rotations in various subject matter expertise.

pros: lots of talented people.  structured and flat hierachy. good benefits.  world class standards in banking quality.
cons: political and lots of self centred and overly aggressive people.  some slack while some work like a horse.  one retrenchment exercise nearly every year with security posted on every floor at ORL building during the fateful retrenchment Friday.  lots of "foreign talent".  Sometimes senior management chose to retain a manager whos causing others to leave because of that person.

review_title: Incompetence. If you're the best player in a team you're in a wrong team.
job_title: Assistant Vice President (Software Engineer) in Singapore
pros:
Close to none
Depending on a team you get to you can make some influence on technology stack used. Depends on how powerful your boss is in their informal hierarchy
cons:
They try to cut costs on everything including you. And they're bad at real cost-saving software development practices
- Absolutely no chance of promotions and very low chance of payraise until 3 years with them no matter what you do. Be prepared to lower or none year bonus, they will find some excuse
- All roadmap solutions are dictated from HK office. HK people are very off the ground, not updated and play their political games
- Political games played all around. If your boss is successful in it, you can get along even with not delivering features you agreed upon. If your boss is not successful - you cannot rely on your peers to supply dependencies you need for your work. And you will be blamed for not completing such work by teams dependant on you
- Every team wants to show off by the number of products it 'owns'. When it comes to problems in products or new features requests then everyone tries to avoid responsibility
- Don't buy their flattering labels, depending on team you can be even VP writing code day and night trying to hit the deadline someone had set for you
- Sometimes due to political games several teams are working on the two copies of the same product competing each other and bosses fight over who's doing the right thing
- Bosses value opinions of expensive vendors over opinions of employees 
- They would declare they try to replace vendors with employees, but keep signing in new vendors instead of hiring people
- Vendors are also into political games pitching their own interests
- Nobody cares about real operational costs of software created, most of code is created so that some manager can put it in his done list. If they cared about operational cost, they should start shutting down most of useless software
- Some products don't have any customer or business value or even have negative value
- Many teams never heard of agile methodologies, but they think they practise scrum
- Many colleagues will be the ones staying with the bank for long time with their knowledge outdated. Some of them will be in positions to make decisions directly affecting your work
- Office space is poorly managed huge openspace without perks at all (basic water taps, fridges, microwaves, overpriced indian cafeteria, vending machines with coffee or snacks)
- Office space has 'free seating policy', but every team has designated area. You will not have your desk, but you will have to use the same desk day to day
- All work is done at slow virtual machines. Forget about laptops, you can only request one - used by 100+ people before you - for a week of training or business trip.
- Work from home is organised using your personal hardware (!!!) and usb access card

review_title: Credit Suisse is a great working place for non-IT jobs but a so-so working place for IT staff

review_title: Warning: Do your due diligence and consider carefully before accepting
pros: Health benefits and that is just about it; apart from the strong brand name and reputation.
cons:
Organization Structure
i)  Due to budget cuts, certain departments have become very lean. Many departments are top heavy with ratio of one actual working analyst/executive to 4 directors (managers and above).  
ii) Frequent restructurings occur due to change in senior management. Most of them are politically driven which affect the day-to-day work and “business-as-usual” of the lower level. 
iii) Like most organizations, internal politics are common. Innocent employees will get caught in the crossfire.

Poor Management and Weak Culture. 
i)	Weak company results led to low bonuses (for certain departments) and huge attrition. They would rather hire contract staffs and keep resources lean. In view of the low bonus and high contract staffs, most employees have a very “silo” style of working.  Employees carry a “watch-your-own-back” and disengaged attitude at work to protect themselves first. 
ii)  The huge attrition reflects weak culture and poor management.
iii) Internal processes are lacking or lost in transition due to staff attrition and offhsoring. Knowledge has been lost in some cases. Most of the best practices are either verbal or handed over from generation to generation without proper documentation. New joiners will not have a clear picture of certain processes and/or how things are done and handled.
iv) As a result of the attrition and restructuring, roles were filled by employees with little or no relevant experience in order to quickly fill in the vacancies/new roles. The poor job fit saw the hiring of leaders or managers with the inability to make effective decisions, poor leadership and ineffective management skills. This also led to mismanagement in the career of the affected employees.  
v) Very slow career progression (below average) with almost no visible path for development. Depending on department, management makes promotion almost unattainable. 

Inefficient Management of Resources 
i) Offshoring and Globalization of resources resulted in internal inefficiencies. Work related issues ranging from HR to IT are remotely operated. A lot of time is wasted on sending screenshots and waiting for someone in another time zone to respond to your issues. Cultural and language issues have not been considered when the company decides to offshore these functions, e.g. first and last name wrongly reflected in the main intranet system by someone from another region who is not familiar with the first and last name of the people from that particular region resulting in a lot of time being wasted to rectify the error as this was also fed into other systems maintained by other teams. A lot of simple issues could be resolved easily with just having someone onsite and without having unnecessary tickets to be raised in addition to having few different people from different parts of the world contacting the person for the rectification works. 
ii) A lot of work that has been offshored have processes that were either lost in translation or transition. Some of these resulted in a lot of internal inefficiencies in having to try to understand changed or new processes that came with the offshoring resulting in possibly some duplication of work or unnecessary work. 

Offshoring and Contract Hiring led to Substandard HR Practices
i) The exit interview is conducted via an automated online survey that is crafted in a conniving manner that does not allow the employee to clearly explain the main reason(s) for leaving.
ii) The lack of interaction from HR also shows that the company does not value its employees

pros: The IT infrastructure is more developed than some of its peers. For instance, colleagues from different regions can hold video conference calls and share screens with each other. This is certainly a pro for Business Analysts.
cons: The company is pushing through aggressive cost-cutting plans to move jobs to low-cost locations. Working with teams with Poland, London or even New York certainly poses a challenge to efficiency as well as work-life-balance.

review_title: Good job but stressful at times
pros: Well known company, that invests in branding - working there you are part of this. People may know little about your country of origin but they will know what it means that you work for Credit Suisse. Lots of opportunities - it hard to hire, so opportunities are frequently available to in-house talent. You can acquire next-level leadership skills and learn about self-management a lot. A lot of off-work initiatives, where you can network and make friends. There is money for business-related activities, once you prove you need something, the company will happily pay. Throughout working there, I felt the company is generally good in valuing good performers, especially technical staff or people will can-do attitude. Internal mobility programs are great - you can change the job internally and your current manager will not be able to stop you. They will also not be informed that you are interviewing or seeking opportunity. Very well structured program.
cons: Firefighting is the most frequent activity. Not many employees have the luxury of uninterrupted brainwork, especially on leadership positions, which is sad. Sometimes you may feel overwhelmed with how many meetings, emails, initiatives the company drives. Visibility is a thing. You may try to promote a good employee, but they will be rejected for 'lack of visibility', which is hard especially for non-leadership promotions. Being a manager, you usually cannot plan your week, as the environment there is so fast-paced and changing. This is exciting for the most of time, but then you may get overwhelmed and burnt-out. A lot of legacy systems and a lot of hands-on-management of these.

pros: * Highly Skilled team with strong Acceptance Criteria for Code Submission * CS allows and rewards employee willing to look beyond the expectation. -> Optimization, architecture, Knowledge Sharing and other
cons: * Coffee is not free.... * Top-down decision that doesn't make sense. No added value on the business or on the metrics. Requirement made just for Senior manager to be "impactfull" on every project they touch.

review_title: Lack of flexibility, old school management style
pros: Transparency in promotions Friendly people Competent team leaders
cons: High pressure especially when the company is going through bad days. the management requires presence at the office for absolutely no reason you just sit there and do the same job, only less productively which was the reason why I left. They have work from abroad policy but in reality it is never approval as if they hate employee having good time or having work-life balance Pay disparity among people doing the same work

job_title: Information Technology Director in New York, NY
pros: I wish I could say something positive... as it would mean hope in our future working for this bank.
cons: Unfortunately, it is one of the worst companies I've ever worked for. Sad but true. Management behaves as if everything is normal and we're expected to go above and beyond for a company that has stated "no profit, no bonuses" at their earnings call. Being in IT, I have no say on profit, except of course to cut, cut, and cut costs everywhere (since we don't know how to make money anymore). Talk about motivation. All I want is get out.

review_title: Lots of red flags...seriously stay away
pros: This is a good stepping stone for early careers and there are lots of nice/helpful people...that's it though.
cons: Management is TRASH. Constantly and consistently demeaning/demoralizing. Low/middle management is useless, upper management is completely disconnected from reality. HR does not even exist outside of an automated chatbot. Nobody wants to see you successful, you will not be paid adequately for 2x or even 3x the work that you should not even be responsible for in the first place. Got laid off because they lost a few too many billions and decided everyone else had to pay for it. For your own good, please stay away.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, CFO in London, England
pros: Some of the benefits offered; Fully Funded Private Healthcare for you and dependents, 13% Non Contributory Pension, can purchase critical illness insurance for you and partner etc. People generally speaking are nice.
cons: Far too many strategic reviews, all EXB now in Switzerland means London & other locations are forgotten. Big push on culture at the bank but its awful, no real promotion based on meritocracy or pay reviews/compensations, its all based on how well you are liked and if your face fits. Swiss staff get some amazing perks......additional holiday when promoted, discounts locally etc. These are not seen in any other location so its very much a them and us relationship......staff morale is terrible loads of people moving before compensation day and this includes senior management too (Dir+ population). Everyone is just waiting for the axe to fall and those moving are moving because they are cutting back everything incl. severance package.

pros: Fair compensation, opportunity for bonus although over 4 years has been small, decent 401k options
cons: For a company so concerned with getting their employees to come back to office, it is interesting to see a lack of management presence. There is no supervision over who has returned except from management, yet management seems to be completely remote, while the culture on campus grows more toxic and self-regulated by low level employees. Although internal mobility is encouraged, these issues plague the entire campus and there is little point to accepting the same treatment in a different occupation for the company. With the company always ending up in the news for issue after issue, combined with a plummeting reputation and stock price, you'd think that it would try harder to keep its remaining talent happy. The amount of experienced professionals who have left during my time is mind-boggling, but at least Credit Suisse helps the local job market stay flush with candidates for organizations that provide a decent work environment.

pros: Good salary Good resources to do the job

pros: - Work from home - Relaxed, not really difficult and pressure This applies for both Risk and Compliance departments where I worked.
cons: - very bureaucratic Requesting something outside of scope of the work is almost impossible. - No knowledge sharing The principle is “just what you need to know to do your job”. Often information is controlled especially when dealing with Client data. - Highly redundant Often one encounters a director conducting the meeting , and having a project manager taking notes and making decks. - Decision-making is too complicated There’s definitely too much people involved - Software development experience is a nightmare Many legacy systems. Installing or developing something locally often requires a hack or is just impossible. For example, No access to some open source packages. - Difficult to move internally to other sections of the bank. The bar is just as high as for someone applying from the outside. - Planned restructuring until 2025 9,000 jobs worldwide; 2400jobs just in Switzerland. Do not apply now, specially in Investment Bank.
